ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I think this is one of the classes that has been most instrumental for my learning at Yale to the use in my postgraduate time. I really appreciate the effort Professor Sakthivel has put in my class. I believe I will use this class to better understand N. Africa in the future.

I learned a lot about North African history and modern politics. We got to take a number of different approaches as well to various questions: ethnographic, more standard poli sci, and more. I felt like I learned a lot!

I learned about the political structures and post-colonial histories of countries in the Maghreb. We used a variety of research approaches to analyze and compare the countries of interest in this course.
The course is really good at teaching the intersection of political science, history, anthropology and sociology. It was really interesting learning when to apply which area to a given topic.
I gained more in depth knowledge of Algeria's and Morocco's political history and the socio-cultural context that has shaped the countries current political climates.
I gained a more complex understanding of the politics, history, and anthropology of the North African region.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I loved the effort, the Arabic knowledge, and the discussions in the class.
I wish the professor had let the class be more open. I would have enjoyed reading other students reading responses. I think it would have improved my ideas and knowledge on North Africa.
I loved the varied approaches to each topic and the diversity of readings. No particular weaknesses.

This course is well-organized, Professor Sakthivel is knowledgeable of the field, and our assignments felt conducive towards our learning. This is one of the classes that I feel as though I learned the most. I also enjoyed the guest speakers. They were interesting and informative.
Readings are very interesting for the most part, and the weekly reading responses mean everyone is actually discussing papers theyve actually read.

I loved the way this course was organized - really great readings, and the progression of topics each week felt natural and logical. We always had really great discussions, and the class was a great balance of lecture and conversation. Professor Sakthivel does a great job of drawing everyone into the conversation without making it stressful or unnatural.
This course is super interesting and engaging. Professor Sakthivel is a great facilitator of the class's conversation, which was always fun to participate in.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think the content learned has been the most useful of all courses at Yale.
Absolutely! It's extremely interesting, well-designed, and intellectually challenging.
Yes, any student with a major that the course encompasses or generally interested in the Middle East & North Africa should take this course.
100%. Readings were explanatory enough for people with passing understanding of North African politics and deep enough for people with better footing
Yes most definitely, the professor's incredible and the course materials are very interesting.
This course is a super fun time, I highly recommend it for anyone that is seeking to gain a better understanding of the region. The guest speakers were also really cool.

Yes! Great professor and super interesting topics that range across fields of foreign policy, ethnography, geopolitics, and sociology. You have ample freedom to write on subjects you're interested in. Professor Sakthivel is extremely intelligent and provides extensive feedback on your writing. There is a high reading work load that you have to read in-depth, so remaining consistently engaged in the course is important to do well. Overall well worth it, and a very intersectional class.

extras.title: AFST 304 01/ANTH 344 01/MMES 304 01/PLSC 458 01 - Modern North Africa in Flux
